question:
Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Two hours after a 2280-g male newborn is born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old primigravid woman, he has 2 episodes of vomiting and jitteriness. The mother has noticed that the baby is not feeding adequately. She received adequate prenatal care and admits to smoking one pack of cigarettes daily while pregnant. His temperature is 36.3В°C (97.3В°F), pulse is 171/min and respirations are 60/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows pale extremities. There is facial plethora. Capillary refill time is 3 seconds. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 70%
Leukocyte count 7800/mm3
Platelet count 220,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 38 mg/dL
Calcium 8.3 mg/dL
What is the most likely cause of these findings?". If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: In this term neonate born at 38 weeks’ gestation to a 22-year-old primigravid woman, the constellation of low birth weight (2280 g), early postnatal symptoms within 2 hours (two episodes of vomiting, jitteriness, and inadequate feeding), tachycardia (171/min), tachypnea (60/min), mild hypoxemia on room air (oxygen saturation 92%), peripheral pallor with facial plethora, and delayed capillary refill (3 seconds) occurs alongside a markedly elevated hematocrit (70%) with normal leukocyte count (7800/mm3) and platelet count (220,000/mm3) and metabolic derangements (serum glucose 38 mg/dL; calcium 8.3 mg/dL). This phenotype is characteristic of fetal chronic hypoxemia with compensatory erythropoiesis and postnatal hyperviscosity, most commonly driven by intrauterine exposures that impair uteroplacental oxygen delivery. The mother’s report of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily throughout pregnancy provides a specific etiologic exposure known to induce fetal hypoxemia via nicotine-mediated placental vasoconstriction and carbon monoxide–related reductions in oxygen carrying capacity, thereby predisposing to intrauterine growth restriction and neonatal polycythemia with downstream hypoglycemia and perfusion abnormalities. The infant’s temperature of 36.3°C (97.3°F) and the immediate timing of symptoms further support an antenatal origin rather than perinatal infection or postnatal environmental causes. Maternal smoking during pregnancy.
content.source_2: The clinical picture in a 2280-g male newborn evaluated 2 hours after birth at 38 weeks’ gestation—characterized by vomiting, jitteriness, inadequate feeding, tachycardia (171/min), tachypnea (60/min), oxygen saturation of 92% on room air, pale extremities with facial plethora, and capillary refill time of 3 seconds—combined with laboratory documentation of a hematocrit of 70% (with leukocyte count 7800/mm3, platelet count 220,000/mm3, serum glucose 38 mg/dL, and calcium 8.3 mg/dL) is most consistent with the hyperviscosity syndrome attributable to excessive red cell mass. In neonates, a venous hematocrit ≥65% defines pathologic erythrocytosis, and associated microcirculatory sludging can produce impaired tissue perfusion (prolonged capillary refill, pallor), respiratory compromise (tachypnea with oxygen saturation 92%), and neurologic irritability (jitteriness), while metabolic sequelae such as hypoglycemia (38 mg/dL) and low-normal to reduced calcium (8.3 mg/dL) frequently accompany the disorder. The absence of leukocytosis and thrombocytosis underscores a selective increase in erythrocyte mass, aligning the observed signs and symptoms directly with increased blood viscosity from elevated hematocrit. Polycythemia.
content.source_3: Among term infants, neonatal polycythemia presents in the immediate postnatal period with feeding intolerance (poor feeding and vomiting), neurologic irritability (jitteriness), tachycardia (171/min), tachypnea (60/min), and cutaneous findings of facial plethora with peripheral pallor and delayed capillary refill (3 seconds), often accompanied by mild hypoxemia (oxygen saturation 92% on room air) and metabolic disturbances (serum glucose 38 mg/dL; calcium 8.3 mg/dL). Diagnostic confirmation rests on a markedly elevated hematocrit, here 70%, with otherwise unremarkable leukocyte (7800/mm3) and platelet counts (220,000/mm3), indicating an isolated expansion of red cell mass sufficient to produce hyperviscosity. Epidemiologically, small-for-gestational-age status (2280 g at 38 weeks) and antenatal exposures such as daily maternal cigarette use are recognized risk factors that drive intrauterine hypoxia and increased fetal erythropoietin, culminating in excessive neonatal erythrocytosis and its early clinical manifestations. The infant’s presentation 2 hours after birth and temperature of 36.3°C (97.3°F) further align with the classic temporal and physiologic profile of this condition. Neonatal Polycythemia.
